did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence to and from Ada Peirce McCormick relating to her family, friends and business ventures. Of particular interest are the letters contained in the Correspondence, Cabot Files and Tarbell Files series as they provide insight into the attitudes, character and pursuits of Ada Peirce McCormick and provide a good source of biographical material.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Ada Peirce McCormick papers (MS 327). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ada Stetson Peirce was born in Bangor, Maine, on March 28, 1888, to Mellen C. and Ann Hayford Peirce. The youngest of four children, she grew up in a prosperous and conservative environment. Ada's post-secondary education included the Ogontz School, Garland School of Homemaking, Boston School of Social Workers, a brief stint at Radcliffe, and the University of Arizona, where she earned a degree in 1932. In 1912, while in Williamsport, Pennsylvania, she met Fred Culver McCormick through a mutual acquaintance. The two married on July 31, 1915, after carrying on a long-distance romance. They moved to Williamsport where Fred worked in his father's insurance business. From 1925 to 1930, Ada gave lectures on marriage and homemaking at various eastern colleges, establishing a national reputation.

The McCormicks relocated to Tucson, Arizona, in 1931 for health reasons. Fred joined the University of Arizona faculty as Professor of English and served as the managing editor of the Arizona Quarterly. In 1937, Ada Peirce McCormick (APM) started the Chapel of Wandering Scholars near the University of Arizona. It later became Cabot Chapel and, in 1954, was incorporated as the non-denominational Little Chapel of All Nations to "promote the God-seeking impulses in mankind."

APM was active in community affairs on a number of different fronts. In 1942, she lobbied to create a recreational facility in Tucson for African-American soldiers, an effort that met with heated opposition from many Tucsonans. The Negro United Service Organization presented her with a commendation for her controversial work. APM's passion for social justice and human rights prompted her to found Letter, a national quarterly devoted to promoting dialogue on national and international problems and to better relationships between individuals and nations. The first issue appeared in January, 1943. Although it soon became an irregular quarterly, subsequent issues contained works by noted authors and APM editorials on relationships and international concerns. Letter gave numerous awards to individuals in various fields for their moral courage, intellect and devotion to country. The last issue was printed in 1948.

A published author and prolific letter writer, APM conducted research on myriad issues and corresponded with many of the social and political leaders, academics, industry executives, and literary figures of her time. Over the years APM received many awards and recognitions for her accomplishments, including, in 1960, the University of Arizona 75th Anniversary Medallion for her religious work with students. Preceded in death by her husband, APM passed away August 4, 1974. For additional information on her life, see: Ada: The Biography of a Woman Ahead of Her Time, by Roger J. O'Mara. (Call number, F29 B2 M36 1988).

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into eleven series:

Note on arrangement: The Ada Peirce McCormick Collection, when received, was well-ordered with the material falling logically into several record sets, or series. Since most of the record creator's original file headings provided an accurate description of the folder contents, they have been retained. However, some of the contents were rearranged for clarity in order to satisfy external research needs. Because correspondence is the dominant record type found in the collection and the contents relate to a broad range of topics, it did not seem logical to group them all under one series titled "Correspondence." Rather, letters are arranged within the appropriate series with the correspondents duly noted. The archivist feels that this will not affect the overall integrity of the collection, but facilitate future use.

list.item: Series I: Correspondence, Ada Peirce McCormick (APM) and Fred Culver McCormick (FCM), 1903-1976
Series VI: APM Articles and Research, 1926-1962

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence to and from APM relating to her family, friends and business ventures. Of particular interest are the letters contained in the Correspondence, Cabot Files and Tarbell Files series as they provide insight into the attitudes, character and pursuits of APM and provide a good source of biographical material.
See the series descriptions below for a fuller narrative of each.

item.corpname: Little Chapel of All Nations (Tucson, Ariz.)

did.unittitle: Series I: Correspondence, Ada Peirce McCormick (APM) and Fred Culver McCormick (FCM), 1903-1976

scopecontent.p: Contains eleven rolls of microfilm. Rolls 1-5 consist of APM's business and personal correspondence from 1942-1974. Roll 1 includes an index to correspondence from April, 1947, to February, 1961. Roll 5 ends with news clippings and write-ups on the life of APM that span the years 1912-1976. Rolls 6 to 8 contain correspondence between APM and FCM (1912-1966). Found in these files are their love letters, plans for marriage, discussions on their faults and good points, and thoughts on religion. Rolls 9 to 11 comprise correspondence between FCM, friends, and relatives (1903-1965).

did.unittitle: Index to APM correspondence; APM correspondence. April 1947-February 1961, September 1942-September 1944
FCM and Ada S. Peirce correspondence. 1912-October 1915

scopecontent.p: Constitutes the bulk of material in the collection and reflects APM's diverse interests, her involvement in activities at the local, national, and international levels, as well as her career as a writer and editor. Materials include correspondence, drawings, manuscripts, newspaper clippings, photographs, and printed material. Much of the correspondence is between APM and authors who submitted poems and stories for publication in Letter. The researcher will note that some of the materials are dated after APM's death in 1974. In these cases the items are most often correspondence from one of APM's employees and deals with closure on a specific concern or issue.

scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, most of it between APM and her godparents, Richard C. (RCC) and Ella Lyman Cabot (ELC). Their long relationship produced a large volume of correspondence, with much of the content providing keen insight into APM's attitudes and opinions on life, marriage, and spiritual issues. After the death of ELC in 1934, RCC recruited APM to write the Cabot's biography, a task she never finished, although the Radcliffe Quarterly published APM's essay on ELC the following year. Her letters, drafts, and other material related to the project are contained within. Apart from the missives between APM and the Cabots is her correspondence with Alice O'Gorman, long-time secretary to RCC, Faith Cabot Pigors, RCC's niece, and her daughter, Phillipa Weld. Some of these letters regard the research and writing of the Cabot biography. Researchers should note that the letters from ELC and RCC to APM were copied and the originals sent to the Cabot Collection at Harvard University.

scopecontent.p: Comprises correspondence, notes, reminiscences, and newspaper clippings. The bulk of material pertains to APM's friendship with mentor, Ida M. Tarbell (IMT). A journalist and biographer by profession, Tarbell served as consulting editor to Letter Magazine until her death in 1944. Most of the correspondence is between APM and IMT; however, there are several folders containing correspondence to and from IMT's relatives, and the McCormicks and Viola Roseboro, a manuscript reader for McClure's magazine and personal friend of IMT. Some originals were copied and sent to the Ida M. Tarbell Collection at Allegheny College (Pa). APM transcribed IMT letters to her family during the years 1891-1894 and these are found in a notebook. Drafts of APM's unpublished biography of IMT can be found in the Manuscripts series.

scopecontent.p: A prolific writer whose interests knew few bounds, APM composed many essays and short stories, a number of which appeared in print. Her short story, "Richard," a biographical sketch on Theodore Roosevelt's grandson, appeared in a 1924 issue of Harpers. APM occasionally wrote under the pen name Charity Howard. Includes related correspondence.

Series VI: APM Articles and Research, 1926-1962

scopecontent.p: Contains the musings of APM on a wide variety of issues, some in the form of correspondence to friends and colleagues. Most are written in a publishable format, although it is unclear if any of the pieces were submitted for publication or appeared in print. Included are the Arthur Herzog and Kinsey Report materials. APM hired Herzog, a former student at the University of Arizona, to do research on assorted topics. The content of the files reflect his findings. APM objected to the conclusions of the Kinsey Report regarding human sexuality and wrote several responses.

scopecontent.p: : Consists of correspondence, newspaper clippings, course outlines, and scrapbooks. The material reflects APM's teaching experiences in schools and organizational settings, especially her courses on marriage and the art of living.

scopecontent.p: The bulk of material consists of news clippings and articles about APM and Letter Magazine and related correspondence. The series also contains awards, certificates, and commentaries on the activities of APM. Some of the material overlaps and duplicates items found elsewhere in the collection.
